 I. URBAN TRANSPORT IN THE RIO DE JANEIRO METROPOLITAN REGION A. Background 1.1 This project has its origins in two major developments at the federal and state level: (a) the decentralization of the Rio de Janeiro Urban Trains from the Federal Government to the State of Rio de Janeiro which took place in December 1994 (as part of an ongoing Bank loan 3633-BR); and (b) the decision of the new State administration which took office in January 1995 to achieve a more effective integration, of all modes in the Rio de Janeiro Metropolitan Region (RJMR), with an aim of reducing subsidies/to urban transport agencies and substantially increasing the participation of the private sector in the operation and investment of the sector. 1.2 The State decided to embark on a program of staff rationalization and restructuring of its urban transportation agencies as part of a State Reform Project. To consolidate the gains made in the decentralization project and substantially increase private sector participation in its metropolitan rail agency (Flumitrens), the State requested the assistance of the Bank to complete the rehabilitation of Flumitrens and the integration with other modes. The identification mission took place in November 1995, and based on its findings, the Bank agreed to proceed with the evaluation of the project provided the State of Rio de Janeiro (SRJ) would incorporate into its urban transport strategy the following two elements: (a) effective coordination between the state and municipal governments of the Rio de Janeiro Metropolitan Region (RJMR); and (b) a formal financing mechanisms considered crucial to create an enabling environment for the long-term financial sustainability of the Rio de Janeiro Metropolitan Region's urban transport systems; and (c) concession, sale or liquidation of all its urban transport agencies. The SRJ moved swiftly and diligently to include these elements in its strategy. B. Despite an existing 264-km rail network, the lack of integration between the Metro (only 23 km) and the Flumitrens discourages more rail trips, in favor of buses and the automobile, creating heavy congestion during peak hours and significantly increasing home-to-work trip time. Rio's geography and topography with its hills and tunnels is prone to traffic congestion, especially when accidents occur and/or cars break down. There is limited space for fully segregated busways. It is estimated that each "carioca" (citizen of RJ) wastes 10-15 days a year more

The main users of the public transport system are from the Baixada Fluminense (a poor section of Rio) and bear the brunt of the system's problems: (a) shortage of capacity at peak hours, resulting in overcrowded (>10 passlm2), (b) long work joumeys (2.5-4.0 hours/day for a round trip) from the metropolitan periphery to thie urban centers, with often more than two modal transfers; and (c) paying over a fourth of their income towards fares. Lack of coordination between the three levels of government responsible for urban transport, particularly between the SRJ and the RJM, has led to poor tariff and modal integration, lack of prioritization in urban transport investments, and no common policy on pricing and subsidies. 1.5 A Bank-financed Mass Transportation Plan (PTM, see Annex 13, Ref. 1) was completed in 1995 and selected the main urban transport corridors of the RJMR as the area most in need of rehabiilitation or new investments. This selection of corridors was based on comprehensive traffic survey data and a demand modeling exercise with a modal split analysis comparing the several modal alternatives for each corridor. The top-ranked group of corridors in terms of economic efficiency for the region was the one formed by the Flumitrens metropolitan rail system, which could provide rail transport services for many of the current road-based urban trips thereby decreasing bus congestion and improving trip times for the users provided Flumitrens can provide an acceptable level of service in terms of frequency and reliability. Alternative options such as busways were not considered feasible given the volumes of passengers involved and the amount of expropriation and resettlement that would be required. To achieve the level of service required, the PTM recommended that the Flumitrens system be further rehabilitated and modernized to be able to carry a daily passenger load of 1.4 million passengers by year 2002. The PTM also recommended a regional transport coordination commission with representation from the State, Rio de Janeiro Municipality, and other municipalities of the RJMR, users and operators be formally established to serve as a forurrm for the discussion and recommendation of nevi major investments and common pricing and subsidy policies. Furthermore, the PTM emphasized the need to better integrate the predominantly bus-oriented RJMR system with Flumitrens, the Metr6 and the ferry. The Bank project team reviewed the reports prepared under the PTM and endorsed the results of the! alternative analysis as well as the proposal for the establishment of a regional transport coordination commission and a more integrated urban transport system. Finally, as recommended by the PTM, the State should put in place the necessary financing mechanisms to ensure the sustainability of the sector in the long run and prevent the deterioration caused by deferred maintenance. The above recommendations agree with earlier Bank's departmental Economic Sector Work (Annex 13, ref. 19) which set the foundations for the ongoing process of decentralization of railway systems from the Federal to the State government. 1.6 Although the project team agreed with the recommendation of the PTM that Flumitrens infrastructure and equipment needed to be rehabilitated, the main concern was to ensure that the system be managed with a private sector orientation and would be able to overcome the problems of mismanagement and inadequacy of maintenance budget which are common to most state-run railways world-wide. Based on the conclusions of studies (financed under Ln. 3633-BR) on options for private sector participation in Flumitrens, the project team organized several brainstorming meetings with the key State decision-makers, and the result of this exercise was an agreement that the best option to ensure an adequate level of service and the financial sustainability of the system would be a full concession to the private sector of its operations and maintenance for a period of not less than ten years. The second best alternative would be the concessioning out of some key railway activities such as rolling stock maintenance and track infrastructure to the private sector while the system would be still run by a state-appointed administration. In all cases, however, there was a consensus that after the completion of the ongoing Ln. 3633-BR which supported the decentralization of the Flumitrens system from the Federal Government to the State, there would still be a need for large-scale rehabilitation of the remaining rolling stock because the lack of maintenance funds prior to decentralization of the system led to the immobilization of almost 50 percent of the fleet. Based on the few similar experiences in the world and since these type of concessions are normally negative (i.e., with a subsidy at least in the first 5 years), the private sector is only interested in bidding if the bid for the concession includes a State-financed investment plan. The project team also agreed that, since the process of concession which started with the State Reform Loan would take at least one year and a half, it was necessary to allow Flumitrens to start its investment plan prior to concession since its fleet availability was very low despite the cars rehabilitated under Ln. 3633-BR. The risk of starting the rehabilitation prior to concession would be that the concession may not materialize and a number of contracts would have been signed. However,

Thus it was decided that the benefits of starting the investment plan before the concession is signed outweigh the risks of not having a concession signed by the agreed date. 1.7 Recent departmental Economic and Sector Work (Annex 13, ref. 19) concluded that particulate air pollution in the northern part of the Rio Municipality and the Baixada Fluminense is serious enough to cause significant health damages including premature mortality. Although these particulates are mostly from industry, they are also due to transport emissions and solid waste buming. Data on ground-level ozone is lacking but climatic conditions and emissions characteristics would suggest the possibility of a serious ozone problem in Rio. Ozone (smog) is mainly due to transport emissions of NOx and VOC (ozone precursors). Traffic congestion in tunnels make them unbearable due to poor ventilation. In 1994 the number of vehicles registered in the RJMR was 1.7 million. Vehicular air pollution has been somewhat mitigated by the use of alcohol. Vehicular accidents, on the other hand, have become a major source of environmental risks. Congestion and overcrowding of the public transport system are a source of envirunmental stress. Throughout the day and particularly at peak-hours noise levels are well above the acceptable levels recommended by WHO. 1.8 After the liquidation of the only state-owned company (CTC), all bus services are provided by private operators at one of the lowest fares in the country. The bus private operators do not receive subsidies while Flumitrens (suburban trains), Metro (subway) and CONERJ (ferries) received subsidies of respectively US$188 million, US$109 million and US$30 million in 1995. Annex 4 details each of the urban transport agencies under state jurisdiction. The CTC was recently liquidated as part of the State's move to privatize urban transport services. Bids for the concession of old CTC routes were issued by June 30, 1997.Finally, RJMR needs to modernize its traffic engineering and control technology to be able to cope with the present and growing number of road-based vehicles and introduce policies which will discourage the rapidly growing use of automobiles for home-to-work trips. 1.9 The road network is radial and converges on the central business district. The commercial speed of the buses in the reserved bus lanes is around 30 km/hr but drops to 20 km/hr or less in the central business district. At peak period, most highway corridors are clogged with bumper to bumper buses and automobiles. Bus services are generally of low speed and unreliable at peak hours due to the congestion. Although they are privately operated, the municipal bus routes are allocated on the basis of competitive bidding and regulated by the Secretary of Municipal Transport, a municipal agency. The privately operated intermunicipal bus services are under the jurisdiction of the Secretary of Transport of the State. Tariffs are set by those agencies and there are no subsidies paid to private bus operators. In the Rio de Janeiro Municipality (RJM), there is a flat tariff which applies to all the municipality and every trip. In the case of the intermunicipal services the tariffs are distance-based. 1.10 At present, Flumitrens, the State-owned suburban railway is partially integrated with 150 bus lines in 30 terminals, which generates about 47 percent of its demand without an integrated tariff. Flumitrens is also integrated with the Metro in 3 stations of which the most important is D. Pedro II. Flumitrens estimates that with more frequent services, increased train availability and reliability, rehabilitation of 13 stations, 5 intermodal integration terminals, and a number of pedestrian crosswalks, demand would increase substantially. For passengers who have their origins and destinations within walking distance of the stations, Flumitrens offers the most comfortable and reliable mode of transport. However, if the origins and destinations are beyond a reasonable walking distance, the lack of good integration and the lack of stations at important demand generation centers, makes the use of the system awkward and more expensive. This lack of sufficient integration between Flumitrens and buses discourages more rail trips and encourages bus and automobile usage, thereby increasing the heavy congestion during peak hours and significantly increasing home-to-work trip time. In its program to decentralize the responsibility of operation of its metropolitan systems from the Federal Government to the State (Ln. 3633-BR), a first attempt at improving integration was made, but it fell short of its goals mainly because the train fleet available at the time the State took over the system was well below what had been estimated at appraisal, due to a lack of promised Federal budget resources for routine and periodic maintenance.

Institutional Responsibilities for Urban Transport in the RJMR 1.11 There are three main government bodies responsible for overseeing the urban transport sector in the RJMR: (a) the State Secretary of Transport (SECTRAN) which regulates all the intermunicipal bus services, rail-based and ferry-boat services of the region; (b) the Secretary of Transport of the Municipality of Rio de Janeiro which regulastes municipal bus services and is also responsible for traffic management and control in the RJM; and (c) the State Directorate for Roads (Departmento de Estradas de Rodagem do Estado do Rio de Janeiro, DER-RJ) responsible for all the state iroads in the SRJ. Urban transport responsibilities within any of the other municipalities of the RJMR are under the jurisdiction of the Prefeitura of that municipalit,y. Intermunicipal services fall under the jurisdiction of the State. At present, although the RJM and the other municipalities of the RJMR are the main beneficiaries of Flumitrens' system, the Metr6, and ferry services, they do not have direct contributions to either the capital or operating budgets of urban transport agencies. This is a situation which must be addressed through formal financing mechanisms since it is only reasonable that they pay their lair share in the provision of transport services which benefit the employers and users in their territoiries. 1.12 Municipal bus operators have a clearing house (Camara de CompensaQao) for bus tariffs, and they pay bus services according to a standard cost formula which they approve. In this manner, they compensate bus companies which operate with tariffs below the estimated cost of the formula. Intermunicipal bus services do not have a clearing house and do not receive a subsidy from the government. 1.13 Since three levels of government have been formulating policies and regulating urban transport without a formal coordinating arrangement, there has been a lack of consistency in the fares chargEid by similar or competing modes, duplication of investments, absence of criteria to prioritize investments, and only embryonic modal integration. This has led to bus services continuing to operate in corrido,rs in which Flumitrens operates (especially since the introduction of the flat tariff in the municipality), expensive and time-consuming disagreements on whether to build a light rail transport, the lack of promotion for hub and spoke services, disparate subsidy policies often based on non-economic considerations, and the absence of user representation in the urban transport decision-making process. Recently, there has been an effort to integrate rail and intermunicipal bus services. The creation of a Regionial Transportation Coordination Commission (RTCC) would ensure that this cooperation would not depend on the political parties in power. 1.14 The lack of a coordinating entity with a unified approach to cost-recovery policies and the lack of effective oversight by the State and the Municipality have resulted in the poor definition of priorities in the RJMR, limited modal and tariff integration, and operating agencies which have no pre-set operational and financial targets. The SRJ as part of this project has established the Ag6ncia Metropolitana de Transporte Urbano (AMTU-RJ) which will fulfill the functions of a RTCC as described in Annex 3. As required by the proposed project, the SRJ and RJM signed a convenio to create the AMTU- RJ. A formal AMTU-RJ was established by a governor's resolution in January 1997. D. Key Sectoral Issues 1.15 There are a number of key issues which must be addressed to improve the supply of urban transport services and to guarantee their orderly development and sustainability in the long term in the RJMR. They are: (a) capacity and safety issues; (b) institutional issues; (c) regulatory issues; (d) cost recovery and financial management issues; (e) poverty alleviation and subsidy targeting; (f) environmental issues; (g) transport planning issues; and (h) private sector participation in investments and operations. 1.16 Capacity and Safety-Related Issues. First and foremost is the need to increase the supply of adequate cost-efficient peak-hour capacity in order to guarantee an acceptable level of service to the average commuter under reasonable safety conditions. This can be done by: (a) rehabilitating and restructuring Flumitrens; (b) building new mass transit systems (busways, LRTs) which prove to be the best alternative from the technical, economic and, especially, financial standpoint; (c) improving traffic
 management through appropriate traffic engineering equipment in order to better manage available road space and reduce congestion; and (d) reducing traffic and transit accidents through a combination of transit safety education campaigns, law enforcement, and appropriate traffic engineering. The proposed project would mainly strengthen Flumitrens' carrying capacity. 1.17 Institutional Issues. These are: (a) the fine-tuning of relations between state and municipal governments and a clear definition of their respective roles in the financing, planning and operation of urban transport services in accordance with the 1988 Constitution; (b) the creation of an entity which is formally empowered by the RJMR for planning, coordinating and setting priorities for new investments and modal integration including tariff setting and cost sharing, in order to assure a minimum of planning continuity; and (c) the appropriate modification of regulation, including the elimination of any remaining regulatory barriers which might prevent free entry and/or competition in the market for provision of transport services especially bus services. The proposed project was instrumental in achieving the establishment of an RTCC. 1.18 Cost Recovery and Financial Management Issues. The need to address cost recovery from a more commercial-oriented standpoint by: (a) setting tariffs which, when added to subsidies, cover at least the long-run variable costs (defined as out-of-pocket costs plus depreciation of equipment and cost of capital) of the service provided and by controlling fare evasion; (b) setting appropriate peak and off-peak pricing; (c) improving the financial management of the systems by wide ranging cost-cutting measures, staff rationalization policies, and by appointing more financial managers to run the mass transit systems; and (d) revamping funding mechanisms in order to guarantee adequate financing for the implementation of new mass transit systems and the sustainability of the existing systems. All the above issues would be addressed by the proposed project, through the concession. 1.19 Adequate Targeting of Subsidies. Blanket subsidies paid to operators, such as the ones paid to Flumitrens/Metr6/CTC/CONERJ, ought to be eliminated. However, urban households have been devoting increasingly large proportions of their incomes to transport, and transport-related expenditures have become a considerable burden on local government budgets. The appropriate targeting of urban transport subsidies and their extension to the informal sector which is not presently covered by mechanisms such as the "vale-transporte" is a major issue which must be addressed in the short term. Appropriate mechanisms for financing such subsidies (tariff differentiation, contracted budgetary transfers, etc.) and channeling them (tokens, multimodal passes, differential tariffs) need to be designed. Tariff policies, subsidies and financing mechanisms were carefully studied during the preparation of the proposed loan, and a law to establish formal financing mechanisms for urban transport was submitted to the state legislature. 1.20 Environmental Issues. A reduction of the environmental impacts of urban congestion and noise pollution in the urban area would be brought about through cleaner and quieter systems. The assessment of the potential role of market-based incentives to address pollution and implement, to the extent possible, the polluter pay principle (PPP) to minimize the fiscal burden implied by de facto govemment subsidies to polluters; design the allocation of responsibilities across government levels for the enforcement of the law and definition of tougher standards. The Rio Special Environmental Control Fund (FEEMA) must be equipped to monitor vehicle emissions and noise. An extensive environmental review of the RJMR has been recently completed by the Bank and its recommendations have been taken into account in this proposed loan. 1.21 Planning Issues. There is a need to strengthen RJMR's transportation planning, traffic data base, traffic management, and the economic and financial evaluation of new investments, especially the proposed systems for the Niter6i-S.Gongalo link and the extension of the Metr6 to Barra da Tijuca. This could be done quite easily if there is a formal coordinating agency for urban transport in the metropolitan region. The proposed project would strengthen planning capacities and the data bases of the RJMR. 1.22 Private Sector Participation. The concession in full or by group of activities or sale to the private sector of each urban transport agency and its assets, namely Flumitrensl Metr6/CTC/CONERJ, might be a way to ensure that the level of service provided is respected and the infrastructure and equipment are properly maintained. In Flumitrens, the maintenance of the rehabilitated
 -6 - fleet must be taken very seriously to avoid what is now happening (fleet availability is down to 58 percent). Furthermore, it is through privatization that some urban systems were able to arrest the chronic fare evasion experienced in state-owned organizations. Early indications suggest fare evasion is probably as much as 30 percent in Flumitrens. The SRJ should consider an increase in the private sector participation in investment and operations of its systems. The concession of Flumitrens, Metr6 and CONERJ and the sale of CTC were agreed upon in the State Reform Loan and would be consolidated under the proposed project. 1.23 In the future, urban transport policies in the RJMR should be geared toward the efficient and equitable provision of urban transport services, in particular for low-income groups which have traditionally received less attention. Policies should be consistent with broad transport sector objectives, as well as with the objectives of the urban subsector. In accordance with the 1988 Constitution, the policies should support the decentralization of urban transport services from the Federal Government to the St,ates to facilitate modal and tariff integration and respond quickly to local needs. The policies should simultaneously address the need for institutional coordination and an integrated urban transport, land use, and environmental strategy. The general approach is to restore the incentives which exist when privately-owned systems operate under competitive conclitions. Redesigned regulations and concessionary agreements, and improved bidding processes will promote competition in the provision of bus services. Rates should be gradually liberalized in the corridors where there is effective competition. Urban and metropolitan train operations should be owned by tlhe state and/or local governments and operated by private interests operating under concessionary arrangements. Appropriate tariffs and financing mechanisms would enable the efficient operation and development of the systems. Local govemments would continue to be responsible for traffic regulation and management but would improve their capacity to: (a) manage road use; (b) improve traffic management and street maintenance; (c) protect the environment; (d) monitor the effects of regulations and taxation; (e) promote integration of the various transport systems; and (f) coordination with land-use development. E. Lessons from Experience in the Sector 1.24 Initial Bank support for the urban transport sector in Brazil was provided through four urban transport projects totaling US$540 million, of which the First, Second and Third Urban Transport Projects (Loans 1563-BR, 1839-BR, 1965-BR) have been cornpleted. The Fourth Urban Transport Project, which continued the work started in the Third project, was canceled because the government abolished the federal agency in charge of urban transport (EBTU). Additional urban transport projects financed by the Bank (Loans 3457-BR and 3633-BR for US$126 million and US$128 million respectively) support the rehabilitation and decentralization of the CBTU from the Federal to the State governments in SAo Paulo and Rio de Janeiro. Loan 3457-BR (Sao Paulo) became effective on February 3, 1993. Loan 3633-BR (Rio de Janeiro) was signed October 14, 1993 and became effective March 14, 1994. Loan 3633-BR financed a number of studies dealing with the evaluation of options to concession out the Flumitrens and Metr6 and contributed to the preparation of the presently proposed project. 1.25 To build upon the experience of past urban transport projects for the design of the proposed project, an analysis of lessons learned was undertaken (Annex 1). The review was based on Project Completion Reports and Performance Audit Reports (PCR/PAR) in urban transport and urban development worldwide. Recognition was made of trends and changes in project design since the PCRs/PARs were completed. The main lessons identified and incorporated into the design of the proposed project are: (a) Institutional Strengthening. The organizations dealing with urban transport at the federal, state and municipal levels should be reorganized and strengthened. In the medium term, the Bank's strategy will focus on promoting a more efficient and financially sustainable market-oriented supply of public transport services, through: (a) reforming regulations which will facilitate market entry, fare deregulation, and public bidding in route allocation; (b) promoting service differentiation especially in the bus systems; (c) defining eligibility requirements and strengthening funding mechanisms for urban transport to cover operating deficits (based on pre-agreed targets in contract plans) and finance major investments; (d) supporting the evaluation and, if justified, the introduction of new investments such as reserved busways and light rail transport; (e) reducing the environmental impacts of urban transport by setting standards for air quality, noise pollution, and visual intrusion along with indicating who would pay for them and how; and (f) assisting in projects which improve the data base required for appropriate planning such as origin/destination surveys and preparation of master plans which study land use and urban transport alternatives. This Annex outlines the Bank's past support for the Brazilian urban transport sector and the experience gained. The lessons learned can be summarized as: (a) the coordination between the three levels of government in urban transport should be dealt with very carefully at the project preparation level and reviewed in detail during the Mid-term Project Review; (b) policy for the sector should be strengthened to minimize distortions resulting from inefficient physical and financial coordination between modes and to promote multi-modal integration; (c) the tariff levels should allow for significant cost recovery of working costs and should be complemented by financing mechanisms which cover the shortfall; (d) demand levels are often overestimated and should therefore be carefully scrutinized; and (e) more attention should be given to the management of infrastructure maintenance. A. First Urban Transport Project (Ln. 1563-BR, US$88 million, May 1978) 2. Project Objectives. The objectives were to: (a) finance investments that would improve urban transport services, with emphasis on the provision of public transport, especially to the poor; (b) promote and support the development and implementation of aippropriate urban transport policies; and (c) strengthen municipal, state, and federal capacity to prepare, appraise, and execute sound urban transport projects. 3. Project Content. The project was broad in scope and included traffic engineering and management measures in central urban areas and at critical points, the introduction of exclusive bus lanes and segregated busways, widening of critical links, or construction of missing links in the road network, reorganization or construction of bus terminals, paving of bus routes in low-income areas, and training, technical assistance and institutional strengthening to improve the delivery of transport services. Project beneficiaries included five metropolitan regions (Belo Horizonte, Curitiba, Porto Alegre, Belo Horizonte and Salvador). Nine different agencies were involved in implementation and overall coordination was the responsibility of the Brazilian Urban Transport Company (EBTU). 4. Implementation Experience. The project experienced various delays due to: (a) lack of institutional support to the cities from EBTU, and Govemment changes in 1979 which led to staff changes in the various implementing agencies; (b) the preparation of final engineering designs and tendering; (c) land acquisition; (d) availability of counterpart funds; (e) local level coordination; and (f) quality control of the works. The closing date for the project was extended twice, resulting in the implennentation period changing from three years to five years and nine months. This suggests that the appraisal schedule estimate was overly optimistic. Even so, the implementation period was still substantially shorter than both worldwide and LAC region profiles which were above eight years. The only specific covenant not met was the one requiring the five municipalities to take the necessary steps to revise the valuation for tax purposes of properties whose values had been affected by the project. In the early stages of the project, EBTU staff were less forceful than expected in solving local problems and bringing difficulties to the attention of decision-makers. It must be recognized, however, that EBTU was in its formative stages. This was a first project for them and there was a learning process involved. As part of this process, and in order to achieve institutional improvement, EBTU prepared several operational manuals to assist in the appraisal and supervision processes. These manuals and the experilence gained by EBTU (and the Bank) provided the basis for the development procedures applied in the Third Urban Transport Project (1981), which did much to improve the quality and efficiency of EBTU's operations.

The OED concluded that "the project was successful in implementing some of the most imaginative and radical bus priority measures carried out anywhere in the world. The Project Completion Report sums up well the principal lessons: (a) It is not sufficient for the railway service to be successfully implemented. (c) Regarding the original objective of TRENSURB covering its working costs, the appraisal was unrealistic to expect that this would take place during the initial operation period. In the meantime, TRENSURB should review its staff needs in order to streamline costs and carry out a tariff study to determine the optimal user charges. Conclusions and Lessons Learned 28. Despite the considerable achievements of the First Urban Transport Project and the success of the Third Urban Transport Project, the projects have led to the conclusion that several specific issues in the urban transport sector require attention and should be addressed within the context of overall sector reform. The main issues are discussed below. 29. Cost Recovery. Direct cost recovery is difficult in the urban transport sector, other than for self-financing infrastructure and passenger vehicles and vessels. Therefore, transportation infrastructure investments (urban and interurban) conventionally recover costs indirectly through transport-related taxes. In the First Urban Transport Project, it was envisaged that partial cost recovery would take place by the revaluation of properties whose values were affected by the project. No such revision in valuation, however, has apparently taken place in any of the five Metropolitan Regions (MRs), partly because of the difficulties in assessing an increase in property values through the low-cost improvement schemes provided under the project, when alternative policies or conditions encourage the provision of essential municipal infrastructure, at little or no cost to the beneficiaries. In retrospect, the project should have also addressed the indirect cost recovery mechanisms. 30. Maintenance. Lack of maintenance is clearly a problem in each of the five MRs in the First Project, and is now apparent in the components implemented early in the Third Urban Transport Project. Problems apply to a wide range of components. Maintenance covenants were included in the agreements for both projects, but this has proved an ineffective mechanism for ensuring adequate maintenance levels. While there is increasing awareness of the problem and while improved maintenance standards are an objective of the Federal Government, there is a need to develop an institutional and financial framework and capability to provide the necessary funding and to carry out the appropriate maintenance. In hindsight, this problem probably reflects the limitation of addressing narrow sectoral issues, in isolation of a broader policy framework for the urban sector as a whole.

This federal law created the following MRs: Sao Paulo, Belo Horizonte, Porto Alegre, Recife, Salvador, Belem and Fortaleza. The Rio de Janeiro Metropolitan Region (RJMR) was created later, by a similar Federal Law, number 20, dated 7/1/74, along with the merger of the former states of Guanabara and Rio de Janeiro. 2. According to the 1969 Brazilian Constitution, the Federal Government was responsible for establishing Metropolitan Regions. The present 1988 Constitution transferred such authority to State Governments. In 1990, the Government of the State of Rio de Janeiro reconstituted the RJMR. It now includes the following municipalities: Rio de Janeiro, Belford Roxo, Duque de Caxias, Guapimirim, Itaborai, ltaguai, Japeri, Mage, Mangaratiba, Marica, Nil6polis, Niter6i, Nova Iguarcu, Paracambi, Queimados, S3o Gon9alo and Sao Joao do Meriti. The law stipulates that the Integrated Planning for the Metropolitan Region will share 'the definition of the policies for: development, land use, urban growth, industrial plant location, dwelling, tourism, pollution, environment control, sewerage, culture preservation and protection, as well as for mass transit, including the permission, concession, authorization and scheduling for transit systems, transfer stations for passenger and cargo." 4. The MRs are managed by a Deliberative Council composed by the following members: * all mayors; * one county deputy selected by each municipality; * five members of the State House of Representatives; * five members of the executive power, nominated by the Governor and chosen from the Secretariat; * one member of the community, nominated by the Governor; * one member of the Civil Society, nominated by the Governor; * the president of the council is the Governor. 5. The key elements for the sustainability of the proposed coordination are as follows: (a) it should be conceived as a permanent structure, designed to outlive executive or legislative mandate periods; (b) it should be accepted by the parties as an additional asset and not as a threat to their

A standard cost-benefit analysis was performed to evaluate the economic impact of the implementation of the proposed infrastructure and equipment component (consolidate the rehabilitation of Flumitrens and build/rehabilitate the transfer stations between the trains, metro and ferries), which represents 96 percent of the total proposed project. This Annex describes the demand analysis and the set of benefits and costs that have been considered in the economic evaluation, as well as the assumptions adopted regarding key inputs, such as the value of time. Direct user benefits include travel time and operating cost savings; indirect benefits arise from the reduction of negative externalities (accident and air pollution costs). Investment costs comprise civil works, permanent way, operating systems, rolling stock, and costs of projects and studies. Both benefits and costs are defined as incremental compared to the situation of the end of the project CBTU/IBRD I (Ln. 3633-BR). Throughout the analysis, and for illustrative purposes, the proposed investments were evaluated with and without the accident and air pollution externalities. A more detailed description of the data and assumptions supporting the economic evaluation summarized in this annex can be found in Reports 8 and 9 in the Project Files. 2. This economic evaluation estimates the discounted expected present value of the infrastructure investment's net benefits, the expected internal economic rates of return, as well as the expected benefit/cost ratios for a set of discount rates, which includes the 10 percent discount rate, which has been defined by SEAIN (Secretary of Planning for the Federative Republic of Brazil), as well by its Commission of External Financing (COFIEX) for the project appraisal of foreign investments. In addition, the sensitivity analysis included in this annex provides an idea of how the economic rates of return would change due to deviations from the value of benefits and costs used in the base case. The analysis is then complemented by a table of impacts of the project which are evaluated on a qualitative basis. B. Choice of a Project Base Case Mass Transit Options 3. Following current Bank policy recommendations for the appraisal of mass transit investments contained in the Urban Transport Policy Paper (World Bank, 1986), the proposed investments were compared against two totally segregated busways with regular buses and a totally segregated busways with articulated buses (Annex 13, ref. 8a). In all cases, the analyses showed that the proposed investments had a higher internal rate of return. C. Demand Analysis Demand Modeling 4. The demand estimates used in the economic evaluation are the result of a simulation of the Rio de Janeiro Metropolitan Region transport network, performed with the Mantra System' microcomputer program. The urban transport demand model used by this program is a classical aggregate four-stage transport planning model, which comprises trip generation, trip distribution, modal Mantra Computer System was developed by Logit - Logistica Informatica e Transportes, Brazil, and SDG - Steer Davies Gleave, England.
 -70- ANNEX 9 split, and trip assignment. This model estimates peak (6 hours) and off-peak (10 hours) periods of public transport demand, which are assigned to bus, metro and railway networks. 5. The model Mantra is integrated with a Geographic Information System, GisPlus. 2 In order to use the model, it was necessary to create a GIS database for Rio de Janeiro Metropolitan Region (RJMR), which comprises a zoning layer and a transport network layer (made up of line and node layers). To develop the databases for the demand study, the team benefited from the existence of a model of the transport network prepared under the Transport Master Plan of the RJMR financed by the Bank. This network was prepared using GisPlus and then imported by Mantra. 6. The zoning system adopted is based on the RJ sub-regions, which were defined in the Rio de Janeiro Master Plan. This zoning system was digitizecl using GisPlus and then imported by Mantra. 7. The present demand study used as primary data the 1994 Household and Origin/Destination (OD) survey undertaken by IPLAN-RIO for the Rio de Janeiro Master Plan based on household samples in all RJMR. From this survey were obtained the following data: transport demand on a daily/hourly basis, breakdown into peak and off-peak period ancd breakdown into trip purposes. 8. Peak hour periods considered were the following: 06:00 a.m. to 09:00 a.m. and 16:00 p.m. to 19:00 p.m. The number of trips in this period corresponds to 56,4 percent of the weekday ridershiip. Both periods have similar number of trips and almost the same peak hour factor. The OD matrix breakdown into trip purposes shows that 56,6 percent of trips are commuter and business trips and 43,4 percent are related to other trip purposes. 9. The steps in the demand modeling exercise were: (a) Trip Generation. This step consists of the estimation of the number of trips which will be produced by and attracted to the area of influence of the projects considered in the study. In the present study it was conservatively assumed that the 1994 OD matrix is a good estimate up to the year 2001. After this year, a yearly demand increase of 1 percent per year was considered. Car and walking trips were not considered at all. (b) Trip Distribution. This step consists of the determination of the origin zone and destination zone for each trip based on the types of trips produced by and attracted to each zone and the interzonal "impedance" values (typically travel times). Also in this case there is the assumption of using the current matrix as an estimate up to the year 2001. (c) Modal Choice consists of the calculation of which trips will use the bus network and the metro system. The Mantra model allows the competition between single modes and combined modes. The modail choice model used is the multinomial Logit model. It is important to point out that for each zone pair of interest, for the area of influence of the Railway lines, there will always be competition between bus and railway+bus and in some cases metro+bus. The model utility functions considered the same values of travel time used in the economic evaluation. Non cash cost of transfer is taken into account as an impedance to choose a mode. (d) Trip assignment consists of the "loadinig" of the passenger trips onto the multi- modal public transport network. The method used to assign the trips made within each model, is the "all or nothing" procedure with no capacity restraint iterations 2 GisPlus is a Geographic Information System developed by Caliper Ccrporation, USA.

D. Benefits Value ofl Time 12. Mass transit projects can hardly be economically justified without accounting for the real resource savings that economies of time represent. The monetary value of time by which the time savings ,are multiplied to obtain the benefits from time savings is a key input in the economic evaluation of the infrastructure components of this project. Individual values of time are traditionally considered to be a function of income, in particular a function of the individual wage level. Thus, the value of time used in the calculation of time savings is derived from the income distribution of users, disaggregated by transport mode and trip purpose, and from information on wage levels. Table 9.2 shows the income of public transport users in the zone of influence of the FLUMITRENS and is disaggregated by mode. The information was obtained from the 1994 Household and Origin/Destination (OD) survey for the Rio de Janeiro MAaster Plan. 13. The base minimum wage used was R$112 which at the shadow price of foreign exchange of 1 is equivalent to US$112. From this minimum wage base, the value of fringe benefits was considered separate from payroll taxes. Fringe benefits in Brazil include vacation and the 13th month of salary; both entail scaling the base salary by a factor of 1.25. Commuting and other purpose trips are valued as a proportion of net wages. This implies subtracting direct taxes paid by the employee from the base wage, which includes fringe benefits. The employee is subject to a payroll tax that varies between 8 percent and 10 percent. In addition, the income tax should be subtracted. By assuming that one-third of passengers are not tax-exempt and do not evade taxes, the net wage deflating factor will be in the 0.92- 0.88 range. An average factor of 0.9 was used. Business trips are valued at gross wages, where fringe benefits and payroll taxes are taken into account. Payroll taxes in Brazil vary between 38 percent and 45 percent and about 35 percent are paid by the employer. By combining fringe benefits and employer contribution on payroll taxes, the base wage must be scaled by a factor of 1.60 (1.25 plus 0.35). 14. Hourly wages for each transport mode users are estimated by multiplying the individual wage (in minimum wages) by the value of the minimum wage and dividing the result by 157, the assumed average number of hours worked in a given month. Common practice in the appraisal of urban transport projects is to use a proportion of the hourly wage rate to approximate the value of time saved. This propiortion as well as the wage rate base chosen for the calculation-whether gross or net wages- depend on the type of trip. Three types of trip can be distinguished for the purposes of the analysis: home-to-work trips (or commuting trips), work-related trips (or business trips), and non-work related trips (or other trips), for example shopping or visiting the doctor. E-conomic theory indicates that both commuting trips and other trips should be valued as a proportion of the net wage. Empirical evidence suggests that this proportion may vary between 20 and 100 percent. The value adopted in the economic evaluation was a value of 17.5 percent based on a study undertaken a few years ago for a similar city with the :same type of population. A 20 percent value was tested as part of the sensitivity analysis. Economic theory also indicates that business trips during working hours be valued at 100 percent of the gross wage rate.3 The resulting values of time used in the economic evaluation are summarized in Table 9.5 and the proportion of passenger-hours spent traveling by type of trip is summarized in Table 9.3. When the! value of time is equal to zero the IERR is still 38.17 percent. In developed countries, estimates of the value of time for journey to work ranges from 20 to 100 percent of the gross wage rate. A recent review of the literature concludes that a reasonable average value of time for journey to work is 50 percent of the gross wage rate. The Companhia Fluminense de Trens Urbanos (Flumitrens) was, formed as a separate company fully owned by the State of Rio de Janeiro on December 22, 1994. As part of the decentralization policy for the suburban railways, the Federal Government restructured the Balance Sheet of Flumitrens thereby absorbing all outstanding liabilities while agreeing to finance the ongoing investment program aimed at expanding the system's capacity (CBTU/BNDES Program)4. Under CBTU, STU-RJ (Superintendency for Rio de Janeiro), highly depended upon federal subsidies to meet its operating deficits, to service its debt and to undertake capital investments. While Flumitrens, as well, would continue to depend on external cash infusions, as part of its own financial restructuring, the State of Rio de Janeiro has made an important decision: to increase the efficiency of the system by concessioning it to the private sector. The operating subsidies are, therefore, expected to fall. 2. From a high of 940 thousand paying passengers per day reached in 1984 (CBTU took over the system that year), the ridership has continued to drop every year. In July 1996, there were only 74 trains providing the service while more than 200 stood paralyzed due to lack of spare, parts, accidents, and overhauls. About 17 percent of the revenue is lost to evasion and another amount estimated to be 5-10 percent is not recovered due to high level of ticket fraud. doc.repnme: Brazil - Rio de Janeiro Mass Transit Project
doc.abstracts: The main objectives of the Rio de Janeiro Mass Transit Project are: 1) to improve the quality of urban transport services in the metropolitan region (RJMR) by developing a fully integrated urban transport system; and 2) to substantially improve the level of service provided by the Suburban Train Company (Flumitrens) by reducing operating subsidies and increasing private sector participation in its operations and management. The project has two components: 1) an infrastructure and equipment component that rehabilitates/refurbishes Flumitrens' rolling stock and infrastructure and rehabilitates or builds transfer stations between the trains and other modes (Metro, buses, and ferries); and 2) an institutional and policy development component that helps a) support the process of concessioning Flumitrens to the private sector through technical assistance for preparing and evaluating bids; b) operate the Regional Transport Coordination Commission (RTCC) for the RJMR; c) prepare an integrated Transport Policy, Land Use, and Air Quality Management strategy for the RJMR to meet both transport and air quality targets and to introduce sound cost recovery, tariff, regulatory, and subsidy policies; d) set up a comprehensive staff retraining for Flumitrens; e) prepare feasibility studies and bidding documents for a proposed extension and other priorities of the mass transit system; and f) implement an Environmental and Traffic subcomponent.
